summary: When the body of Army Capt. Elizabeth Campbell (Leslie Stefanson) is found on a Georgia military base, two investigators, Warrant Officers Paul Brenner (John Travolta) and Sara Sunhill (Madeleine Stowe), are ordered to solve her murder. What they uncover is anything but clear-cut. Unseemly details emerge about Campbell's life, leading to allegations of a possible military coverup of her death and the involvement of her father, Lt. Gen. Joseph Campbell (James Cromwell).

Somewhat mixed movie set in the humid claustrophobia of an Army base in Georgia. Travolta, in one of his more human roles, plays Paul Brenner a United States Army Criminal Investigation Command investigator who is on the base undercover brokering an illegal arms deal when his investigation takes a dead end (pun intended) and then takes are far more disturbing left field when the naked and suspected raped body of  Elisabeth Campbell, the daughter of the bases General, is found within an urban training ground strung out with ropes. Brenner, assisted with ex-flame Sarah Sunhill follow the clues in an increasingly disturbing trail of cover-ups and lies. James Woods as Colonel Moore privides a strong foil for Travolta and only Oscar winner Timothy Hutton appears to be dialing in the performance. Greg Hale Jones and Carter Burwell's soundtrack is of particular note. Sure, it strays a little, can be over sentimental and isn't quite as fantastic as other movies of it's ilk. But it's far, far from the currenty 22% score. There are worse movies with higher ratings and maybe it's just a nostalgic thing for me. But I've always enjoyed this movie.

One of the more underrated movies of John Travolta, The General's Daughter is a great whodunnit which makes excellent use of its location (a military base in Louisiana) and its ensemble cast. Travolta is on fine form and charismatic as ever as the investigator who is torn between his urge to find out the truth and his loyalty to the army. Travolta and Madeleine Stowe, who is always an asset in any cast in my opinion, play well off one another and make for a nice couple of investigators. James Woods and James Cromwell shine in crucial supporting roles. Espcecially the scenes with Woods and Travolta crackle with intensity and are full of wordgames and sharp dialogue. The strong atmosphere (enhanced by a great Carter Burwell soundtrack) ,the engrossing mystery (with disturbing themes of rape, sexism, betrayal and parental negligence: themes sadly still relevant to this day), and some good performances make for a more than entertaining watch.

The real crime here is that this movie is based on a true story. I first heard this one in 1978. However, women have been in the American Armed Forces, and facing the rape issue since WWII and probably since Molly Pitcher. But the one I heard about in '78 was a noble soul who reasoned that if she made a big deal out of it, which "they" were expecting her to, "they" would use it as an excuse to keep women out of Military academies and positions from then on. You decide if it made any difference in the long run. Does anyone think rape doesn't still happen in the military? This movie goes AWOL, gets real weird, lands way off target in my opinion. The actual soldier woman gets less screen time than anyone else, how ironic is that? What a gyp. She sounds to me like the female version of Jesus, if she did what she did for the reason I was told she did, by a source in the know. She deserves a better salute than this. Let's hope someone approaches the subject again, but attempts to breathe some actual life into the soldier woman who took rape in stride, because that is what the military is STILL asking rape survivors to do, I hope you know.

In continuing proof that I am totally out of touch with the general viewing public, I found this to be watchable and interesting. Travolta was likeable and interesting, and the story was also interesting. My only real negatives were the over-the-top acting by Clarence Williams (remember "Mod Squad"?) and James Woods. And I mean WAY over the top with Clarence Williams. And my other minor problem was the way that everything was so clearly explained at the end, like they wanted to make absolutely sure we got it. Other than that, it was a good, watchable, military crime "who dunnit". I suppose some were a bit shocked and disturbed that the daughter had a kinky side, but as films go that was quite tame, IMO. Unlike, say "Se7en" with Morgan Freeman and Brad Pitt. Geez, now THAT was disturbing. Anyway, I'd call it a good, watchable movie.

The General's Daughter was just as bad as everyone said it was, but Michele has a thing for Madeline Stowe and I have a thing for Jimmy Woods, so we rented it. Ugh. I've developed a theory-- it takes a great screenwriter to get a good movie out of a mediocre novel (for example, the chap who did the screenwriting for Hitch, who transformed many a bad book into an excellent film-- did Hitch do his own screenwriting?). And GD didn't have a great screenwriter, or even a good one. Travolta, however, does a spot-on Georgia accent. Oh, yeah-- and a shoo-in for most annoying soundtrack of the year and most annoying song of the year ("Sea Lion Woman," which should be stewed in a fire kindled from its own sheet music).  1/2
